Expectation1: Respond to emails and messages within a reasonable time frame
Situation1: The team awaits a clarification before progressing with a shared task.
Situation2: They remain cheerful and patient while handling an upset customer during a peak holiday rush.
Story: The line at the register snakes past the bakery, and the woman in front of me is growing more agitated with every beep of the scanner. She’s upset about a coupon not working, her voice rising, and I force a smile, trying to keep my tone calm and friendly. My phone buzzes in my pocket—again. I know it’s my team at the office, waiting for my reply about the project. They can’t move forward until I clarify a detail, and I promised to be responsive, even on my lunch break. But right now, I’m the only cashier on duty, and the holiday crowd is relentless. The customer glares, expecting my full attention, while my colleagues expect a quick answer. My heart pounds as I juggle the register, the customer’s frustration, and the insistent vibration of my phone. I feel pulled in two directions, each role demanding something I can’t give at the same time.
